channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Editor's note: Reporting the midair collision will focus on facts and people's stories
item.description: NPR's reporting will continue to focus on what happened and learning what we can about the victims and telling their stories.
item.content:encoded:
NPR's reporting will continue to focus on what happened and learning what we can about the victims and telling their stories.

(Image credit: Petty Officer 2nd Class Taylor B/U.S. Coast Guard)
item.dc:creator: Russell Lewis

item.title: The latest on the fatal midair plane and helicopter crash
item.description: Video footage of the incident shows the aircraft flying at a low altitude, before an explosion happened at the moment of impact. The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating.
item.content:encoded: Video footage of the incident shows the aircraft flying at a low altitude, before an explosion happened at the moment of impact. The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating.
item.dc:creator: Ayana Archie

item.title: What is RFK Jr.'s favorite bird? Why is this woman smiling? Find out in the quiz!
item.description: This week was hard on the conflict-averse. But if you're up on nursery rhymes, prehistoric bodily fluids and Renaissance art, you'll get at least three right this week.
item.content:encoded: This week was hard on the conflict-averse. But if you're up on nursery rhymes, prehistoric bodily fluids and Renaissance art, you'll get at least three right this week.
item.dc:creator: Holly J. Morris

item.title: Going to weddings and birthdays can be pricey. How to cut costs or gracefully decline
item.description: If your social calendar is burning a hole in your wallet, there are steps you can take to spend less while maintaining good relationships.
item.content:encoded: If your social calendar is burning a hole in your wallet, there are steps you can take to spend less while maintaining good relationships.
item.dc:creator: Andee Tagle

item.title: 8 things to know about Groundhog Day and its big star, Punxsutawney Phil
item.description: The weather-predicting groundhog celebrity has met two presidents and drinks a life-extending elixir: "Our Phil is like, probably 139 years old," Groundhog Club Inner Circle President Tom Dunkel says.
item.content:encoded:
The weather-predicting groundhog celebrity has met two presidents and drinks a life-extending elixir: "Our Phil is like, probably 139 years old," Groundhog Club Inner Circle President Tom Dunkel says.

(Image credit: Jeff Swensen)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: Radhika Veharia reflects on peace — and Grammy acclaim — in a quiet ashram
item.description: In a small ashram nestled on a quiet residential street near Laguna Beach, Radhika Vekaria is finding peace after receiving her first ever Grammy nomination.
item.content:encoded:
In a small ashram nestled on a quiet residential street near Laguna Beach, Radhika Vekaria is finding peace after receiving her first ever Grammy nomination.

(Image credit: Raymond Alva for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Kira Wakeam

item.title: Did DEI D.I.E.? Welcome to a new kind of 'civil rights' era
item.description:
The new Trump administration is using the language of civil rights but flipping it on its head. If 'diversity' is now being coded as discrimination, what does that mean for the future of civil rights?

Brittany is joined by Columbia Law professor Olatunde Johnson and Pulitzer prize-winning journalist Wesley Lowery to look at how the Trump administration is dismantling federal diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives and how private businesses are following suit.

Support public media and receive ad-free listening. Join NPR+ today.
item.content:encoded:
The new Trump administration is using the language of civil rights but flipping it on its head. If 'diversity' is now being coded as discrimination, what does that mean for the future of civil rights?

Brittany is joined by Columbia Law professor Olatunde Johnson and Pulitzer prize-winning journalist Wesley Lowery to look at how the Trump administration is dismantling federal diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives and how private businesses are following suit.

Support public media and receive ad-free listening. Join NPR+ today.
item.dc:creator: Brittany Luse

item.title: Study finds India doubled its tiger population in a decade
item.description: The study found that some local communities near tiger habitats have also benefited from the increase in tigers because of the foot traffic and revenues brought in by ecotourism.
item.content:encoded:
The study found that some local communities near tiger habitats have also benefited from the increase in tigers because of the foot traffic and revenues brought in by ecotourism.

(Image credit: Satyajeet Singh Rathore)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: A New Zealand mountain is granted personhood, recognizing it as sacred for Māori
item.description: The recognition acknowledges the mountain's theft from the Māori after New Zealand was colonized. It fulfills an agreement from the country's government to Indigenous people.
item.content:encoded:
The recognition acknowledges the mountain's theft from the Māori after New Zealand was colonized. It fulfills an agreement from the country's government to Indigenous people.

(Image credit: Dita Alangkara)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Senator calls RFK Jr.'s position on race and vaccines dangerous
item.description: In one of the most tense exchanges in a heated confirmation hearing, Senator Angela Alsobrooks called out past comments RFK Jr. made suggesting a different vaccine schedule for Black people.
item.content:encoded:
In one of the most tense exchanges in a heated confirmation hearing, Senator Angela Alsobrooks called out past comments RFK Jr. made suggesting a different vaccine schedule for Black people.

(Image credit: Tom Williams)
item.dc:creator: Will Stone
